page.title: 06LOUDOUN ESTATE-GALSTON
page.content: Loudoun Estate was at it's height in the early 19thC when the castle was known as "The Windsor of Scotland". Loudon Estate is mainly covered in an extremely deep boulder clay layer.It is this layer not the underlying rock that determines soil type and,unfortunately this boulder clay has produced a very poor soil. Due to bad management of the 1000 acre estate down through the years and bad drainage caused by the boulder clay layer,farming on the Loudoun estate is not good so the estate could never become profitable on farming alone. The estate can't make good use of it's farmland potential.Instead by opening it's doors to the public it may pave the way to a brighter future. It has already well developed clay pigeon and pheasant shoots,nature trails and a horsejumping area.
